message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of stool and family history suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is commonly associated with MEN2A syndrome. A rectal suction biopsy will confirm the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum and help confirm the diagnosis. Options B, C, and D are not specific for Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of meconium passage and family history of MEN2A syndrome suggest Hirschsprung disease. Rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard test for diagnosis and confirms the absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon. Atrophic nerve fibers and decreased acetylcholinesterase activity are associated with Hirschsprung disease but are not diagnostic. A barium enema may show a narrowed or absent segment of colon but cannot confirm the absence of ganglion cells. Rectal manometry may show decreased rectal compliance and poor relaxation of the internal anal sphincter, but it is not diagnostic on its own.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of stool in the rectal vault suggests Hirschsprung’s disease, which is commonly associated with MEN2A syndrome. Rectal suction biopsy demonstrating absence of ganglion cells confirms the diagnosis. Options B, C, and D are not diagnostic for Hirschsprung’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of stool in the rectal vault and family history of MEN2A syndrome suggest Hirschsprung's disease, which is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of ganglion cells in a rectal suction biopsy. Option B describes features of diabetic autonomic neuropathy. Option C describes a finding in patients with Hirschsprung's disease, but it's not the confirmation of the diagnosis. Option D is a feature of normal rectal function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of MEN2A syndrome suggests Hirschsprung disease, which is confirmed by the absence of ganglion cells demonstrated by rectal suction biopsy. Options B-D are not used for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is commonly associated with MEN2A syndrome. Diagnosis is confirmed by rectal suction biopsy, which will show the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum. The other options are not specific for Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of stool in the rectal vault in a newborn boy with a family history of MEN2A syndrome suggests Hirschsprung disease. Absence of ganglion cells demonstrated by rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. Atrophic nerve fibers and decreased acetylcholinesterase activity are seen in Hirschsprung disease but are not diagnostic. A barium enema can demonstrate absence of a transition zone, but a rectal biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis. Rectal manometry demonstrating relaxation of the internal anal sphincter with distension of the rectum is also used in diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease, but biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of meconium and family history of MEN2A syndrome suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is confirmed by an absence of ganglion cells demonstrated by rectal suction biopsy. Options B, C, and D are not diagnostic for Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of failure to pass meconium and family history of MEN2A syndrome suggest Hirschsprung disease. The definitive diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is based on the absence of ganglion cells demonstrated by rectal suction biopsy. Option B describes findings in autonomic neuropathy, not Hirschsprung disease. Option C describes findings in patients with chronic constipation but not Hirschsprung disease. Option D is a test used to diagnose anorectal malformations, not Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with Hirschsprung disease, which is associated with MEN2A syndrome. The definitive diagnosis is made by a rectal suction biopsy demonstrating an absence of ganglion cells in the affected portion of the colon. Option B describes findings in patients with neuropathic constipation, while options C and D are used to diagnose functional constipation.
